intro: Peucedanum mildbraedii, commonly known as the Kashmir angelica, is a perennial herb native to the Himalayan regions of India and Pakistan. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its roots are often used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Peucedanum mildbraedii thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in forested areas at high altitudes.
